measured_by: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5)
justification: The review introduces MDD by stating, “According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), MDD is predominantly characterized by low mood and/or loss of interest or pleasure,” indicating DSM-5 criteria were the diagnostic standard.
Sample descriptions repeatedly report BDI scores (e.g., “BDI 29.2 (10.5) [Severe]”), showing that depressive symptoms were quantified with the Beck Depression Inventory.
For Kuhn et al. participants, the article lists “HAM-D 28.6 (5.7) [Severe],” demonstrating use of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale to measure depression severity.
Several study samples are characterized with BAI scores (e.g., “BAI 17.8 (9.1) [Moderate]”), indicating anxiety symptoms were assessed via the Beck Anxiety Inventory.
The table note clarifies abbreviations, including “HAM-A = Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale,” signifying that anxiety levels were measured with the HAM-A in the summarized studies.
When detailing conditioned responses, the review notes, “two studies measured SCR,” signifying that skin-conductance responses served as the physiological measure of Pavlovian fear learning.
The article states, “three studies measured fear potentiated startle,” indicating that electromyographic measurement of startle reflex was used to index the conditioned fear response.
